briefdescription.para: The default rangeCurve to use when an empty wrapper is created. It's a super basic and smooth closed curve from 0 to 0.
The number of decimal places used in the range- the number of zeroes is the number of decimal points, e.g: 10 == 1dp, 100 == 2dp, 1 == 0dp (whole numbers)
The ID of this track- used to find and manipulate it in custom code.
The name of this track for use (and easy identification) in the inspector. This is usually in the format of {ID}, {range.x} - {range.y}

The range of tunes in which this track can be heard. If a RadioOutput.Tune value is within this range, the tune power of this track will be > 0, and it will be audible (not counting spatial components+gain+etc)

detaileddescription.para: This range is clamped between RadioData.LOW_TUNE and RadioData.HIGH_TUNE

briefdescription.para: The curve defining the loudness of the track over its range. The progress between range.x and range.y the RadioOutput.Tune value is, is the progress along this curve the tune power is.

listitem.para: If the curve is the default curve (smooth from 0 to 1 to 0), it will smoothly get louder towards the center of the range, and quieter towards the edge.
If the curve is a flat line at y=1, it will be the same volume across the entire range
If the curve is a line from 0 - 1, it will be louder the further along the range the tune is, getting loudest at range.y
If the curve is goes up and down repeatedly, it will be at various different volumes depending on what you set, moving between them along the range

briefdescription.para: An added value to the volume of the track. This is applied before any other volume is calculated.
The amount that this track gets quieter when another track is playing on top of it (and it's above this track in RadioData.trackWs.
If true, this track ignores any RadioBroadcaster influence and plays everywhere.
If true, this track plays on RadioData.Init() - usually on game start.
A wrapper class for RadioTrack so that track types can be switched between in the inspector! Also contains various values that are track-agnostic.

detaileddescription.para: This is how a RadioTrack is stored and accessed in RadioData. If we didn't use a wrapper like this, you wouldn't be able to choose trackType in a dropdown and see it change in the inspector- it's not possible (to my knowledge) to do that without some kind of wrapper and [SerializeReference]. Wrappers also contain variables that exist for every track type, such as range and gain.
